'''Adur Burzen-Mihr''' was an [[Atash Behram|Atash Bahram]] (a [[Zoroastrianism|Zoroastrian]] [[fire temple]] of the highest grade) located in [[Parthia (region)|Parthia]]. In the [[Sasanian Empire|Sasanian]] period it was one of the three [[Legendry Great Fires|Great Fires]] and was associated with the farmer class; the other two were [[Adur Farnbag]] in [[Pars (Sasanian province)|Persis]] which belong to the priest class, and [[Adur Gushnasp]] in [[Media (region)|Media]], which belong to the warrior class. Its establishment can be dated to the late 5th or early 4th century BC. ''Adur'' means "[[Atar|Holy Fire]]", and ''Burzēn-Mihr'' is a [[Parthian language|Parthian]] personal name literally meaning "Exalted is [[Mithra|Mihr]]", thought to be the name of the temple's founder.
This Fire is described in ''[[Bundahishn]]''. Its location is given as [[Mount Rivand|Mount Rēvand]] (in Avestan: Raēvant), probably a spur of the [[Nishapur mountains]] in the district formerly known as [[Rēvand]] in [[Greater Khorasan|Khurasan]]. An element of the name is preserved in the name of the nearby village [[Borzinan may]]. Another identification is Mount Mehr, five miles from the village [[Mehr, Razavi Khorasan|Mehr]] on the Shahrud–Sabzevar Highway.
The Fire is mentioned several times in ''[[Shahnameh]]'' as Mehr-Barzīn (مهر برزین), Mehr (مهر), and Barzīn (برزین), and is used also as a [[simile]] for fiery fierceness.
The Fire is thought to have been a major center of pilgrimage, even after the [[Arsacids]]' fall. In the Sasanian period, although its name was always placed third in texts and the fire was associated with the lowliest class of the society, (farmers; the other two being warriors and priests), it still maintained its importance. Its history in the Islamic period is not known.
==References== *M. Boyce, “ĀDUR BURZĒN-MIHR,” Encyclopædia Iranica, I/5, pp. 472-473; an updated version is available online at http://www.iranicaonline.org/articles/adur-burzen-mihr-an-atas-bahram-see-atas-i (accessed on 28 February 2014).

'''Aggavaṃsa''' of [[Arimaddana]] (modern [[Bagan]], [[Burma]]) was the author of the [[Saddanīti]], a [[grammar]] of the [[Pāli language]], specifically the text of the [[Buddhism|Buddhist]] scriptures, the [[Tipiṭaka]]. The work was completed in 1154, CE and was taken to Laṅka (Ceylon) a few years after its completion.
It can be seen as a descriptive grammatical work. It consists of 28 chapters with the first 19 being entitled ''Mahāsaddanīti'' (The Greater Guidance of Sadda) and the remaining 9 chapters being called ''Cullasaddanīti'' (The Lesser Guidance of Sadda).The Mahāsaddanīti is in two sections: the Padamālā(1-14)that deals with morphological and syntactic patterns of Pāli and the Dhātumālā(1-14)that gives a full lexicografical account of Pāli roots in eight gaṇas. The Cullasaddanīti is tantamount to the Suttamālā. It is made up of 1347 suttas accompanying an additional chapter on upasaggas and nipātas .

[[File:Antonio Arregui Yarza (2015).jpg|thumb|250px|Antonio Arregui Yarza (2015).]] Msgr. '''Antonio Arregui Yarza''' (born June 3, 1939, in [[Oñati|Oñate]]) is a [[Roman Catholic]] [[Archbishop]].
Yarza is an [[List of people associated with the Pontifical University of St. Thomas Aquinas|alumnus]] of the [[Pontifical University of St. Thomas Aquinas (Angelicum)|Pontifical University of St. Thomas Aquinas ''Angelicum'']] in [[Rome]] where he earned [[Doctor of Canon Law|Doctorate in canon Law]].
Archbishop Arregui Yarza was Auxiliary Bishop of [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Quito|Quito]] and Titular Bishop of Auzegera from January 4, 1990, to July 25, 1995.
He served as the [[Roman Catholic Diocese of Ibarra|Bishop of Ibarra]] from July 25, 1995, to May 7, 2003.
He was appointed [[Archbishop]] of [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Guayaquil|Guayaquil]] on May 7, 2003, replacing Archbishop [[Juan Ignacio Larrea Holguín]].
As of September 2012, he is the President of the [[Conferencia Episcopal Ecuatoriana]] (the Roman Catholic Conference of Bishops of Ecuador).
On Tuesday, September 18, 2012, he was named by [[Pope Benedict XVI]] as one of the papally-appointed Synod Fathers for the upcoming October 2012 Ordinary General Assembly of the [[Synod of Bishops (Catholic)|Synod of Bishops]] on the New [[Evangelization]].<ref>http://press.catholica.va/news_services/bulletin/news/29687.php?index=29687&po_date=18.09.2012&lang=en{{dead link|date=July 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>

Fasting (Sunni Islam) |type = Islamic and national (In some countries such as [[Afghanistan]], [[Azerbaijan]], [[Bahrain]], [[Iran]], [[Lebanon]], [[Pakistan]], [[Bangladesh]], [[Iraq]], [[India]], and [[Indonesia]]) |significance = Marks the martyrdom of [[Husayn ibn Ali]] according to Shia Islam; the day that [[Islamic view of Moses|Moses]] fasted as gratitude for the liberation of the Israelites according to Sunni Islam}} {{Shia Islam}} '''Yom Ashura''' or '''Ashura''' ({{lang-ar|عاشوراء}} ''{{transl|ar|ALA|ʻĀshūrā’}}'') is the tenth day of [[Muharram|Muḥarram]], the first month in the [[Islamic calendar]].{{cite web| url=http://factsanddetails.com/world/cat55/sub359/item1439.html| title=Shiite History Beliefs and Differences Berween Sunnis and Shiites: Muslim Sects and Sunnis| accessdate=January 26, 2015| deadurl=yes| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150202033052/http://factsanddetails.com/world/cat55/sub359/item1439.html| archivedate=February 2, 2015| df=mdy-all}} For the majority of [[Shia]] Muslims Ashura marks the climax of the [[Remembrance of Muharram]], and commemorates the death of [[Husayn ibn Ali]], the grandson of [[Prophet Muhammad]], at the [[Battle of Karbala]] on 10{{nbsp}}Muharram in the year 61{{nbsp}}AH (in [[Tabular Islamic calendar|AHt]]: October 10, 680{{nbsp}}CE).{{cite encyclopedia |last1=Madelung|first1=Wilferd|authorlink=Wilferd Madelung| title=Ḥisayn B. ʿAli i. Life and Significance in Shiʿism | encyclopedia=Encyclopædia Iranica Online | accessdate=November 4, 2014|url=http://www.iranicaonline.org/articles/hosayn-b-ali-i}} Sunni Muslims have the same accounts of these events, but ceremonial mourning did not become a custom - although poems, eulogizing and recounting the events were and continue to be common."My Ashura, My Karbala, My Hussein: A Sunni perspective http://www.huffingtonpost.com/sadok-benabdallah/my-ashura-my-karbala-my-h_b_12517900.html Retrieved February 10, 2017''Fundamentalisms and the state: remaking polities, economies, and militance'' Martin Marty, R. Appleby. University of Chicago Press. 1996 p. 451''Religion, social practice, and contested hegemonies reconstructing the public sphere in Muslim majority societies'' Armando Salvatore, Mark LeVine. Palgrave Macmillan. 2005 p. 93 Mourning for the incident began almost immediately after the Battle of Karbala. Popular elegies were written by poets to commemorate the Battle of Karbala during the [[Umayyad Caliphate|Umayyad]] and [[Abbasid Caliphate|Abbasid]] era, and the earliest public [[Mourning of Muharram|mourning rituals]] occurred in 963{{nbsp}}CE during the [[Buyid dynasty]].{{cite book|last1=Cornell|first1=Vincent J.|author2=Kamran Scot Aghaie|title=Voices of Islam|date=2007|publisher=Praeger Publishers|location=Westport, CN|isbn=978-0275987329|pages=117–18|url=https://books.google.com/?id=y_eGWvPTtikC&dq=Karbala+Umayyads|accessdate=November 4, 2014}} In [[Afghanistan]],{{cite web|url=http://www.worldtravelguide.net/afghanistan/public-holidays|title=Public Holidays in Afghanistan|work=worldtravelguide.net|accessdate=October 10, 2015}} [[Iran]],{{cite web|url=http://www.worldtravelguide.net/pakistan/public-holidays|title=Public Holidays in Pakistan|work=worldtravelguide.net|accessdate=October 10, 2015}} Ashura has become a national holiday, and many ethnic and religious communities participate in it.{{cite web|url=http://www.abna.ir/data.asp?lang=3&id=482977|title=AhlulBayt News Agenc en|date=May 9, 2016|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=http://www.jafariyanews.com/2k5_news/april/12hindusazadari_orissa.htm|title=Hindus holding tasia procession in Orissa for over three centuries - Jafariya News Network|publisher=}} In Sunni Islam, Ashura also marks the day that [[Moses]] and the [[Israelites]] were saved from Pharaoh by God creating a path in the Sea, and is the Islamic equivalent to [[Yom Kippur]].[[Sahih Bukhari]] Book{{nbsp}}31 Hadith 222, Book{{nbsp}}55 Hadith{{nbsp}}609, and Book{{nbsp}}58 Hadith{{nbsp}}279, [http://searchtruth.com/searchHadith.php?keyword=jews+fasting&translator=1&search=1&book=&start=0]; [[Sahih Muslim]] Book 6 Hadith 2518, 2519, 2520 [http://www.searchtruth.com/book_display.php?book=006&translator=2&start=154&number=2514][[Javed Ahmad Ghamidi]]. [[Mizan]], ''[http://www.renaissance.com.pk/novislshar2y4.htm The Fast] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930155610/http://www.renaissance.com.pk/novislshar2y4.htm |date=September 30, 2007 }}'', [[Al-Mawrid]]Morrow, John Andrew. ''Islamic Images and Ideas: Essays on Sacred Symbolism''. McFarland & Co, 2013. pp. 234–36. {{ISBN|978-0786458486}}Katz, Marion Holmes ''The Birth of The Prophet Muhammad: Devotional Piety in Sunni Islam''. Routledge, 2007. pp.113–115. {{ISBN|978-1135983949}} Other commemorations include [[Noah]] leaving the Ark and [[Prophet Muhammad]]'s arrival in Medina.{{cite book |first=Sulafa |last=Abou-Samra |chapter=Muslim Calendar, holy days, and festivals |title=Islamic Beliefs, Practices, and Cultures |p=153 |year=2011 |publisher=Marshall Cavendish |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=H_m14NlQQMYC&pg=PA153 |isbn=978-0761479260}} ==Etymology== The root of the word ''Ashura'' has the meaning of ''tenth'' in [[Semitic languages]]; hence the name of the remembrance, literally translated, means "the tenth day". According to the orientalist A.{{nbsp}}J. Wensinck, the name is derived from the Hebrew ʿāsōr, with the Aramaic determinative ending.A.{{nbsp}}J. Wensinck, "Āshūrā", ''Encyclopaedia of Islam{{nbsp}}2''. Retrieved June 8, 2011. The day is indeed the tenth day of the month, although some Islamic scholars offer up different etymologies. In his book ''Ghuniyatut Talibin'', [[Abdul-Qadir Gilani|Sheikh Abdul Qadir Jilani]] writes that Islamic scholars differ as to why this day is known as Ashura, some of them suggesting that it is the tenth most important day with which God has blessed Muslims.{{cite web|last1=Staff|first1=Writer|title=Top 10 similar words or synonyms for ashura|url=http://wordsimilarity.com/en/ashura|website=wordsimilarity}} ==Historical background== {{Main article|Battle of Karbala}} The Battle of Karbala took place within the crisis environment resulting from the succession of [[Yazid I]].{{cite encyclopedia|last=G.R.|first=Hawting|title=Yazīd (I) b. Muʿāwiya|encyclopedia=Encyclopaedia of Islam|publisher=Brill|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1163/1573-3912_islam_SIM_8000|edition=second|date=2012}}{{cite book|last1=Hitti|first1=Philip K.|title=The Near East In History A 5000 Year Story|publisher=Literary Licensing, LLC|isbn=1258452456|url=https://books.google.com/?id=oOM2PH3IYrMC&q=yazid+succession&dq=yazid+succession|accessdate=September 23, 2016|language=en|year=1961}} Immediately after succession, Yazid instructed the governor of [[Medina]] to compel Husayn and a few other prominent figures to pledge their allegiance ([[Bay'ah]]). Husayn, however, refrained from making such a pledge, believing that Yazid was openly going against the teachings of Islam and changing the [[sunnah]] of Prophet Muhammad.{{cite web|url=http://www.alsunnah.ca/yazid.html |title=Al Bidayah wa al-Nihayah |publisher= }}{{dead link|date=July 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}{{cite web|url=http://www.alsunnah.ca/yazid.html |title=Al-Sawa'iq al-Muhriqah |publisher= }}{{dead link|date=July 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} He, therefore, accompanied by his household, his sons, brothers, and the sons of [[Hasan ibn Ali|Hasan]] left Medina to seek asylum in [[Mecca]]. On the other hand, the people in [[Kufa]], when informed of Muawiyah's death, sent letters urging Husayn to join them and pledging to support him against the [[Umayyads]]. Husayn wrote back to them saying that he would send his cousin [[Muslim ibn Aqeel]] to report to him on the situation, and that, if he found them supporter as their letters indicated, he would speedily join them because an [[Imam]] should act in accordance with the [[Quran]] and uphold justice, proclaim the truth, and dedicate himself to the cause of God. The mission of Muslim was initially successful and according to reports, 18,000 men pledged their allegiance. But the situation changed radically when Yazid appointed [[Ubayd Allah ibn Ziyad]] as the new governor of Kufa, ordering him to deal severely with Ibn Aqeel. Before news of the adverse turn of events had reached Mecca, Husayn set out for Kufa. On the way, Husayn found that his messenger, Muslim ibn Aqeel, had been killed in Kufa. Husayn encountered the army of [[Ubaydullah ibn Ziyad]] along the route towards Kufa. Husayn addressed the Kufan army, reminding them that they had invited him to come because they were without an Imam. He told them that he intended to proceed to Kufa with their support, but if they were now opposed to his coming, he would return to where he had come from. In response, the army urged him to proceed by another route. Thus, he turned to the left and reached [[Karbala]], where the army forced him not to go further and stop at a location that was without water. [[File:20131203 Istanbul 012.jpg|thumb|260px|Name of the Karbala [[Martyrdom|Martyr]] ''Husayn with [[Islamic calligraphy]]'' in [[Hagia Sophia]]]] Ubaydullah ibn Ziyad, the governor instructed [[Umar ibn Sa'ad]], the head of the Kufan army, to offer Ḥusayn and his supporters the opportunity to swear allegiance to Yazid. He also ordered Umar ibn Sa'ad to cut off Husayn and his followers from access to the water of the Euphrates. On the next morning, Umar ibn Sa'ad arranged the Kufan army in battle order. The [[Battle of Karbala]] lasted from morning to sunset on October 10, 680 (Muharram{{nbsp}}10, 61{{nbsp}}AH). Husayn's small group of companions and family members (in total around 72 men and the women and children){{efn|Except his young son, Ali, who was severely ill during that battle.{{cite book|last1=Hoseini-e Jalali|first1=Mohammad-Reza|title=Jehad al-Imam al-Sajjad|date=1382|others=Translated by Musa Danesh|publisher=Razavi, Printing & Publishing Institute|location=Iran, Mashhad|pages=214–17|language=Persian}}}}{{cite web|url=http://www.porsojoo.com/en/node/70869 |title=در روز عاشورا چند نفر شهید شدند؟ |publisher= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130326073754/http://www.porsojoo.com/en/node/70869 |archivedate=March 26, 2013 }}{{cite web|url=http://www.velaiat.com/shshow.asp?rsabs=43&id=kash |title=فهرست اسامي شهداي كربلا |publisher=Velaiat.com |date= |accessdate=June 30, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120629162138/http://www.velaiat.com/shshow.asp?rsabs=43&id=kash |archivedate=June 29, 2012 }} fought against a large army under the command of Umar ibn Sa'ad and were killed near the river ([[Euphrates]]), from which they were not allowed to get water. The renowned historian [[Abū Rayḥān al-Bīrūnī]] states: {{quote|… [T]hen fire was set to their camp and the bodies were trampled by the hoofs of the horses; nobody in the history of the human kind has seen such atrocities.{{cite book|last1=Chelkowski|first1=Peter J.|title=Ta'ziyeh: Ritual and Drama in Iran|date=1979|location=New York|page=2}}}} Once the [[Umayyad Caliphate|Umayyad]] troops had murdered Husayn and his male followers, they looted the tents, stripped the women of their jewelry, and took the skin upon which [[Ali ibn Husayn Zayn al-Abidin|Zain al-Abidin]] was prostrate. Husayn's sister [[Zaynab bint Ali|Zaynab]] was taken along with the enslaved women to the caliph in [[Damascus]] when she was imprisoned and after a year eventually was allowed to return to [[Medina]].{{cite web|last1=Madelung|first1=Wilferd|authorlink=Wilferd Madelung|title=ʿALĪ B. ḤOSAYN B. ʿALĪ B. ABĪ ṬĀLEB|url=http://www.iranicaonline.org/articles/ali-b-hosayn-b-ali|website=ENCYCLOPÆDIA IRANICA|accessdate=August 1, 2011}}{{cite book|last=Donaldson|first=Dwight M.|title=The Shi'ite Religion: A History of Islam in Persia and Irak|year=1933|pp=101–11|publisher=Burleigh Press}} ==Commemoration of the death of Husayn ibn Ali== {{Main article|Commemoration of Husayn ibn Ali}} {{Husayn}} [[Image:Kerbela Hussein Moschee.jpg|thumb|Millions of Shia Muslims gather around the Husayn Mosque in Karbala after making the pilgrimage on foot during [[Arba'een]], which is a Shia religious observation that occurs 40 days after the Day of Ashura.]] ===History of the commemoration by Shia=== According to [[Ignác Goldziher]], {{quote|[E]ver since the black day of Karbala, the history of this family … has been a continuous series of sufferings and persecutions. These are narrated in poetry and prose, in a richly cultivated literature of martyrologies …'More touching than the tears of the Shi'is' has even become an Arabic proverb.{{cite book|last1=Goldziher|first1=Ignác|title=Introduction to Islamic Theology and Law|date=1981|location=Princeton|page=179}}}} The first assembly (''majlis'') of the Commemoration of Husayn ibn Ali is said to have been held by Zaynab in prison. In Damascus, too, she is reported to have delivered a poignant oration. The prison sentence ended when Husayn's 3-year-old daughter, [[Sakina bint Husayn|Sakina]], died in captivity. She would often cry in prison to be allowed to see her father. She is believed to have died when she saw her father's mutilated head. Her death caused an uproar in the city, and Yazid, fearing a potential uprising, freed the captives.{{cite encyclopedia | title=Zaynab Bint Ali | encyclopedia=Encyclopedia of Religion | accessdate=January 19, 2008|url=http://www.bookrags.com/Zaynab_bint_Ali}} Imam [[Ali ibn Husayn Zayn al-Abidin|Zayn Al Abidin]] said the following: {{quote|It is said that for twenty years whenever food was placed before him, he would weep. One day a servant said to him, 'O son of Allah's Messenger! Is it not time for your sorrow to come to an end?' He replied, 'Woe upon you! [[Jacob]] the prophet had [[Tribes of Israel|twelve sons]], and Allah made [[Benjamin|one of them]] disappear. His eyes turned white from constant weeping, his head turned grey out of sorrow, and his back became bent in gloom,{{efn|[http://tanzil.net/#12:84 Quran, 12:84]}} though his son was alive in this world. But I watched while my father, my brother, my uncle, and seventeen members of my family were slaughtered all around me. How should my sorrow come to an end?'{{efn|From Shaykh as-Sadooq, al-Khisal; quoted in al-Ameen, A’yan, IV, 195. The same is quoted from Bin Shahraashoob's Manaqib in Bih’ar al-Anwar, XLVI, 108; Cf. similar accounts, Ibid, pp. 108–10}}{{cite book|last=Sharif al-Qarashi|first= Bāqir|year=2000|title=The Life of Imām Zayn al-Abidin (as)|others=Translated by Jāsim al-Rasheed|location=Iraq|publisher=Ansariyan Publications, n.d. Print}}{{cite book|last=Imam Ali ubnal Husain|title=Al-Saheefah Al-Sajjadiyyah Al-Kaamelah|year=2009|others= Translated with an Introduction and annotation by Willian C. Chittick With a foreword by S. H. M. Jafri|publisher=Ansariyan Publications|location=Qum, The Islamic Republic of Iran}}}} Husayn's grave became a pilgrimage site among Shia Muslims only a few years after his death. A tradition quickly developed of pilgrimage to the [[Imam Husayn Shrine]] and the other Karbala martyrs, known as ''[[Ziarat ashura]]''.{{cite encyclopedia | title=Hosayn B. Ali in Popular Shiism | encyclopedia=Encyclopedia of Iranica | accessdate=December 16, 2010|url=http://www.iranica.com/newsite/articles/v12f5/v12f5036c.html|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080117220431/http://www.iranica.com/newsite/articles/v12f5/v12f5036c.html|archivedate=January 17, 2008}} The [[Umayyad]] and [[Abbasid]] caliphs tried to prevent construction of the shrines and discouraged pilgrimage to the sites.al Musawi, 2006, p.{{nbsp}}51. The tomb and its annexes were destroyed by the Abbasid caliph [[Al-Mutawakkil]] in 850–851 and Shia pilgrimage was prohibited, but shrines in Karbala and [[Najaf]] were built by the [[Buwayhid]] emir [['Adud al-Daula]] in 979–80.Litvak, 1998, p. 16. Public rites of remembrance for Husayn's martyrdom developed from the early pilgrimages.{{cite book|title=Nafasul Mahmoom|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Wv3dBQAAQBAJ&pg=PA12|publisher=JAC Developer|pages=12–|id=GGKEY:RQAZ12CNGF5}} Under the Buyid dynasty, [[Mu'izz ad-Dawla]] officiated at public commemoration of Ashura in [[Baghdad]].{{cite journal|last1=Chelkowski|first1=Peter|title=Shia Muslim Processional Performances|journal=The Drama Review: TDR|date=January 1, 1985|volume=29|issue=3|pages=18–30|doi=10.2307/1145650|jstor=1145650|publisher=MIT Press}} These commemorations were also encouraged in Egypt by the [[Fatimid]] caliph [[Abu Mansoor Nizar al-Aziz Billah|al-'Aziz]].{{cite book|last1=Blank|first1=Jonah|title=Mullahs on the Mainframe: Islam and Modernity Among the Daudi Bohras|publisher=University of Chicago Press|isbn=978-0226056777|page=29|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=r_FExBRnC3YC&pg=PA29&lpg=PA29&dq=Egypt+by+the+Fatimid+caliph+al-%27Aziz,+Ashura&source=bl&ots=6svNcQK9zv&sig=5k-1JVeLpNJcJAJGLPszWbByMwc&hl=fa&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjnturjnMDWAhUMYVAKHXSLDfMQ6AEIZjAN#v=onepage&q=Egypt%20by%20the%20Fatimid%20caliph%20al-'Aziz%2C%20Ashura&f=false}} With the recognition of [[Twelvers]] as the official religion by the [[Safavids]], [[Mourning of Muharram]] extended throughout the first ten days of [[Muharram]]. === Azadari (mourning) rituals === The words ''Azadari'' ([[Persian language|Persian]]: عزاداری) which mean mourning and lamentation; and Majalis-e Aza have been exclusively used in connection with the remembrance ceremonies for the martyrdom of Imam Hussain. Majalis-e Aza, also known as Aza-e Husayn, includes mourning congregations, lamentations, [[Mätam|matam]] and all such actions which express the emotions of grief and above all, repulsion against what [[Yazid I|Yazid]] stood for.{{cite web|last1=Jean|first1=Calmard|title=AZĀDĀRĪ|url=http://www.iranicaonline.org/articles/azadari|website=iranicaonline|year=2011}}[[File:Gesel voor Ashura ritueel - Stichting Nationaal Museum van Wereldculturen - TM-4182-17.jpg|thumb|Ritual scourge for use in the Ashura procession. Syria, before 1974.]] These religious customs show solidarity with Husayn and his family. Through them, people mourn Husayn's death and express regret for the fact that they were not present at the battle to fight and save Husayn and his family.{{cite news| url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/uk/crime/article4620487.ece |work=The Times |location=London | title=Devout Muslim guilty of making boys beat themselves during Shia ceremony | first=Steve | last=Bird | date=August 28, 2008 | accessdate=May 1, 2010}}{{cite web|url=http://www.alarabiya.net/articles/2008/08/27/55577.html |title=British Muslim convicted over teen floggings |publisher=Alarabiya.net |date=August 27, 2008 |accessdate=December 28, 2010}} ===Popular customs=== {{see also|Nakhl Gardani|Rawda Khwani}} [[Image:Muharram (Ta'ziya) procession Barabanki India (Jan 2009).jpg|thumb|Indian [[Shia]] Muslims carry out a [[Ta'zieh|Ta'ziya]] procession on day of Ashura in [[Barabanki city|Barabanki]], India, January 2009.]] After almost 12 centuries, five types of major rituals were developed around the [[battle of Karbala]]. These rituals include the memorial services (''majalis al-ta'ziya''), the visitation of Husayn's tomb in Karbala particularly on the occasion of the tenth day of Ashura and the fortieth day after the battle (Ziyarat Ashura and ziyarat al-Arba'in), the public mourning processions (al-mawakib al-husayniyya or the representation of the battle of Karbala in the form of a play (the shabih), and the flagellation (tatbir).{{cite journal|last1=Nakash|first1=Yitzhak|title=An Attempt To Trace the Origin of the Rituals of Āshurā¸|journal=Die Welt des Islams|date=January 1, 1993|volume=33|issue=2|pages=161–81|doi=10.1163/157006093X00063|url=http://booksandjournals.brillonline.com/content/journals/10.1163/157006093x00063|accessdate=July 17, 2016}}{{subscription required|via=Brill}} Some Shia Muslims believe that taking part in Ashura washes away their sins.David Pinault, "Shia Lamentation Rituals and Reinterpretations of the Doctrine of Intercession: Two Cases from Modern India," History of Religions 38 no.{{nbsp}}3 (1999): 285–305. A popular Shia saying has it that "a single tear shed for Husayn washes away a hundred sins".Nasr, Vali, "The Shia Revival", Norton, 2006, p.{{nbsp}}50 For Shia Muslims, the commemoration of Ashura is not a festival but rather a sad event, while Sunni Muslims view it as a victory God gave to Moses. For Shia Muslims, it is a period of intense grief and mourning. Mourners congregate at a mosque for sorrowful, poetic recitations such as ''[[marsiya]]'', ''[[noha]]'', ''[[latmiya]]'', and ''[[soaz]]'' performed in memory of the martyrdom of Husayn, lamenting and grieving to the tune of beating drums and chants of "[[Ya Hussain]]". Also, [[Ulama]]s give sermons with themes of Husayn's personality and position in Islam, and the history of his uprising. The Sheikh of the mosque retells the Battle of Karbala to allow his listeners to relive the pain and sorrow endured by Husayn and his family and they read [[Maqtal Al-Husayn]]{{cite book|last1=Puchowski|first1=Douglas|title=The Concise Garland Encyclopedia of World Music, Volume 2|date=2008|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-0415994040|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=a90rBgAAQBAJ&pg=PA1053#v=onepage&q&f=false}}. In some places, such as [[Iran]], Iraq, and the [[Arab states of the Persian Gulf]], passion plays known as [[Ta'zieh]] Chelkowski, Peter (ed.) (1979) ''Taʻziyeh, ritual and drama in Iran'' New York University Press, New York, {{ISBN|0814713750}} are performed, reenacting the Battle of Karbala and the suffering and martyrdom of Husayn at the hands of [[Yazid I|Yazid]].In the Caribbean islands of [[Trinidad and Tobago]] and [[Jamaica]] Ahsura, known locally as 'Hussay' or [[Hosay]] is commemorated for the grandson of Prophet Muhammad, but its celebration has adopted influence from other religions including Roman Catholic, Hindu, and Baptists, making it a mixture of different cultures and religion. The event is attended by both Muslims and non-Muslims depicting an environment of mutual respect and tolerance.[http://caribbeanmuslims.com/hosay-festival-westmoreland-jamaica Hosay Festival, Westmoreland, Jamaica]http://old.jamaica-gleaner.com/pages/history/story0057.htm title= Out Of Many Cultures The People Who Came The Arrival Of The Indians For the duration of the remembrance, it is customary for mosques and some people to provide free meals (''nazri'') on certain nights of the month to all people.{{cite web|last1=Rezaian|first1=Jason|title=Iranians relish free food during month of mourning|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/middle_east/iranians-relish-free-food-during-month-of-mourning/2012/12/03/1985ceb2-39f9-11e2-9258-ac7c78d5c680_story.html|website=washingtonpost.}}. [[File:Hussay Celebration in Jamaica.jpg|thumb|A historic Ashura celebration in Jamaica, which is known locally as Hussay or Hosay.]] [[Image:Muharram (Al'am) procession Barabanki India (Jan 2009).jpg|thumb|[[Shia]] Muslims carry out an [[Alam|Al'am]] procession on the day of Ashura in Barabanki, India, January 2009.]] [[File:Tabuik festival.jpg|thumb|[[Tabuik]]s being lowered into the sea in [[Pariaman]], Indonesia, by Shia Muslims.]] [[File:Mourning of Muharram in cities and villages of Iran-342 16 (66).jpg|thumb|Nakhl gardani in cities and villages of Iran]] Certain traditional [[flagellation]] rituals such as [[Tatbir|Talwar zani]] (''talwar ka matam'' or sometimes ''tatbir'') use a sword. Other rituals such as ''zanjeer zani'' or ''zanjeer matam'' involve the use of a ''zanjeer'' (a chain with blades).{{cite web|url=http://www.newstatesman.com/200506060012 |title=Scars on the backs of the young |work=New Statesman |location=UK |date=June 6, 2005 |accessdate=December 28, 2010}} This is not without controversy however as some Shia clerics have denounced the practice saying "it creates a backward and negative image of their community." Believers are instead encouraged to donate blood to those in need.{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2007/01/2008525172518879666.html |title=Ashoura day: Why Muslims fast and mourn on Muharram 10 |publisher=Al Jazeera |date=October 10, 2016}}On Ashura, very few Shia Muslims observe mourning with a blood donation, which is called "Qame Zani", and flailing. This mourning is considered to be a shameless way for most Shia Muslims and most of them are against this kind of mourning.{{cite web|url=http://www.jafariyanews.com/2k5_news/feb/20ashur.htm |title=Ashura observed with blood streams to mark Karbala tragedy |publisher=Jafariya News Network |accessdate=December 28, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110713075037/http://www.jafariyanews.com/2k5_news/feb/20ashur.htm |archivedate=July 13, 2011 }}In some areas, such as in the Shia suburb of Beirut, Shia communities organize [[blood donation]] drives with organizations like the [[Red Cross]] or the [[Red Crescent]] on Ashura as a replacement for self-flagellation rituals like ''tatbir'' and ''qame zani''.Edith Szanto, "Sayyida Zaynab in the State of Exception: Shi‘i Sainthood as 'Qualified Life' in Contemporary Syria," ''International Journal of Middle East Studies'' 44 no.{{nbsp}}2 (2012): 285–99. ==Significance among religions== ===Shia Islam=== [[File:10 Muharram.jpg|thumb|10th of the month of [[Muharrem]]: The [[Ashure]] Day - [[Huseyn bin Ali]] was murdered at [[Karbala]]Turkish Alevis are mourning on this day for the remembrance of the death of Huseyn bin Ali at [[Kerbala]] in [[Irak]]. Remembrance by [[Ja'fari jurisprudence|Jafari]]s, [[Qizilbash]] [[Alevi]]-[[Turkish people|Turks]] and [[Bektashi]]s together in [[Ottoman Empire]].]] On the 10th of the month of [[Muharrem]]{{snd}}The [[Ashure]] Day{{snd}}[[Huseyn bin Ali]] was murdered at [[Karbala]]Turkish Alevis mourn on this day to commemorate the death of Huseyn bin Ali at [[Kerbala]] in [[Irak]]. Remembrance by [[Ja'fari jurisprudence|Jafari]]s, [[Qizilbash]] [[Alevi]]-[[Turkish people|Turks]], and [[Bektashi]]s together in [[Ottoman Empire]] This day is of particular significance to [[Twelver]] [[Shia Islam|Shia]] and [[Alawites]], who consider Husayn (the grandson of Prophet Muhammad) [[Ahl al-Bayt]], the third Imam to be the rightful successor of Prophet Muhammad. [[File:1170488615 RIMG1144.JPG|thumb|Shia devotees congregate outside the [[Sydney Opera House]] in Australia to commemorate Husayn.]] [[File:Mourning of Muharram in cities and villages of Iran-342 16 (47).jpg|thumb|Mourning of Muharram in Iran]] [[File:Ashura procession in Tehran, Iran.jpg|thumb|Ashura procession in Tehran, Iran]] According to Kamran Scot Aghaie, "The symbols and rituals of Ashura have evolved over time and have meant different things to different people. However, at the core of the symbolism of Ashura is the moral dichotomy between worldly injustice and corruption on the one hand and God-centered justice, piety, sacrifice and perseverance on the other. Also, [[Shiite]] Muslims consider the remembrance of the tragic events of Ashura to be an important way of worshipping God in a spiritual or mystical way."{{cite book|last1=Cornell|first1=Vincent J.|author2=Kamran Scot Aghaie|title=Voices of Islam|date=2007|publisher=Praeger Publishers|location=Westport, CN|isbn=978-0275987329|pages=111–12|url=https://books.google.com/?id=y_eGWvPTtikC&dq=Karbala+Umayyads|accessdate=November 4, 2014}} Shia Muslims make pilgrimages on Ashura, as they do forty days later on Arba'een, to the Mashhad al-Husayn, the [[shrine]] in Karbala, Iraq, that is traditionally held to be Husayn's tomb. On this day Shia is in remembrance, and mourning attire is worn. They refrain from listening to or playing music since Arabic culture generally considers music impolite during death rituals. It is a time for sorrow and for showing respect for the person's passing, and it is also a time for self-reflection when one commits oneself completely to the mourning of Husayn. Shia Muslims do not plan weddings and parties on this date. They mourn by crying and listening to recollections of the tragedy and sermons on how Husayn and his family were martyred. This is intended to connect them with Husayn's suffering and [[martyrdom]], and the sacrifices he made to keep Islam alive. Husayn's martyrdom is widely interpreted by Shia Muslims a symbol of the struggle against injustice, tyranny, and oppression.{{cite web|url=http://www.al-islam.org/al-tawhid/paradigm-akhtar.htm |title=Karbala', an Enduring Paradigm |publisher=Al-islam.org |accessdate=December 28, 2010}} Shia Muslims believe the Battle of Karbala was between the forces of good and evil, with Husayn representing good and Yazid representing evil.{{cite book|last1=Dabashi|first1=Hamid|title=Islamic Liberation Theology: Resisting the Empire|date=2008|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-0415771559|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=b9WTAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA192&lpg=PA192&dq=Battle+of+Karbala+was+between+the+forces+of+good+and+evil,&source=bl&ots=k_r-CGZ3Of&sig=9mJPpCeg8r14Mod1YnJjIOR8cRM&hl=fa&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwia-r7Nn8DWAhVCPVAKHdgyAaEQ6AEIQDAE#v=onepage&q=Battle%20of%20Karbala%20was%20between%20the%20forces%20of%20good%20and%20evil%2C&f=false}} [[Shia Imams]] strongly insist that the day of Ashura should not be celebrated as a day of joy and festivity. The day of Ashura, according to [[Twelve Imams|Eighth Shia Imam]] [[Ali al-Rida]], must be observed as a day of rest, sorrow, and total disregard of worldly matters.Ayoub, Shiʻism (1988), pp.{{nbsp}}258–59 Some of the events associated with Ashura are held in special congregation halls known as "[[Imambargah]]" and [[Hussainia]].{{cite book|author=Juan Eduardo Campo|title=Encyclopedia of Islam|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=OZbyz_Hr-eIC&pg=PA318|year=2009|publisher=Infobase Publishing|isbn=978-1438126968|pages=318–}} ===Sunni Islam=== Sunnis regard fasting during Ashura as recommended, though not obligatory, having been superseded by the [[Ramadan]] fast. [[Sahih Muslim]], (Hadith-2499)Emmanuel Sivan. "Sunni Radicalism in the Middle East and the Iranian Revolution". ''International Journal of Middle East Studies'', Vol.{{nbsp}}21, No.{{nbsp}}1. (February 1989), pp.{{nbsp}}1–30 According to hadith record in [[Sahih Bukhari]], Ashura was already known as a commemorative day during which some Makkah residents used to observe customary fasting. Prophet Muhammad fasted on the day of Ashura, 10th Muharram, in Makkah. When fasting during the month of Ramadan became obligatory, the fast of Ashura was made non-compulsory. === Judaism === According to Muslim tradition, the Jews also fasted on the tenth day. According to [[Sunnah|Sunni Muslim tradition]], [[Abd Allah ibn Abbas|Ibn Abbas]] narrates that Prophet Muhammad came to [[Medina]] and saw the Jews fasting on the tenth day of Muharram. He asked, "What is this?" They said, "This is a good day, this is the day when Allah saved the Children of Israel from their enemy and Musa ([[Moses]]) [[Yom Kippur|fasted on this day]]." He said, "We have more claim over Musa than you." So he fasted on the day and told the people to fast.Morrow, John Andrew. ''Islamic Images and Ideas: Essays on Sacred Symbolism''. McFarland & Co, 2013. pp.{{nbsp}}234–36. {{ISBN|978-0786458486}}Katz, Marion Holmes ''The Birth of The Prophet Muhammad: Devotional Piety in Sunni Islam''. Routledge, 2007. pp.{{nbsp}}113–15. {{ISBN|978-1135983949}} This tenth in question is believed to be the tenth of the Jewish month of [[Tishri]], which is [[Yom Kippur]] in Judaism.Prophet Muhammad and the Origins of Islam, Francis E. Peters, SUNY Press, 1994, p.{{nbsp}}204. The Torah designates the tenth day of the seventh month as holy and a fast (Lev.{{nbsp}}16, Lev.{{nbsp}}23, Num.{{nbsp}}29). The word "tenth" in Hebrew is ''Asarah'' or ''Asharah'' ({{Hebrew|עשרה}}), which is from the same Semitic root A-SH-R. According to this tradition, Prophet Muhammad continued to observe the veneration of Ashura modeled on its Jewish prototype in late September until shortly before his death, which the verse of [[Nasi']] was revealed and the Jewish-type calendar adjustments of the Muslims became prohibited. From then on, Ashura became distinct from its Jewish predecessor of Yom Kippur.Prophet Muhammad and the Origins of Islam, Francis E. Peters, SUNY Press, 1994, p. 204. [[File:A tadjah at Hosay.jpg|thumb|A tadjah at Hosay in [[Port of Spain]] during the 1950s]] ==Socio-political aspects== [[File:Sham Ghariban in Imam Reza shrine, Mashhad 13950721 03.jpg|thumb|right|Sham Ghariban ''(the first night in mourn of Husayn)'' in [[Imam Reza Shrine]], [[Mashhad]], Iran]] Commemoration of Ashura has great socio-political value for the Shia, who have been a minority throughout their history. According to the prevailing conditions at the time of the commemoration, such reminiscences may become a framework for implicit dissent or explicit protest. It was, for instance, used during the [[Islamic Revolution of Iran]], the [[Lebanese Civil War]], the Lebanese resistance against the [[Israel-Lebanon conflict|Israeli military presence]] and in the [[1990s Uprising in Bahrain]]. Sometimes the Ashura commemorations associate the memory of Al-Husayn's martyrdom with the conditions of Islam and Muslims in reference to Husayn's [[Live like Ali, die like Hussein|famous quote]] on the day of Ashura: "Every day is Ashura, every land is Karbala".[http://www.islamonline.net/English/ArtCulture/2004/03/article06.shtml IslamOnline – Art & Entertainment Section] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061211012221/http://www.islamonline.net/English/ArtCulture/2004/03/article06.shtml |date=December 11, 2006 }} From the period of the [[Iranian Constitutional Revolution]] (1905–1911) onward, mourning gatherings increasingly assumed a political aspect. Following an old established tradition, preachers compared the oppressors of the time with Imam Husayn's enemies, the [[umayyads]].{{cite encyclopedia |last=Calmard |first=J. | title='AZAÚDAÚRÈ | encyclopedia=Encyclopedia Iranica | accessdate=December 16, 2010|url=http://www.iranica.com/newsite/articles/v3f2/v3f2a063.html|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080504011659/http://www.iranica.com/newsite/articles/v3f2/v3f2a063.html|archivedate=May 4, 2008}} The political function of commemoration was very marked in the years leading up to the [[Islamic Revolution]] of 1978–79, as well as during the revolution itself. In addition, the implicit self-identification of the Muslim revolutionaries with Imam Husayn led to a blossoming of the cult of the martyr, expressed most vividly, perhaps, in the vast cemetery of [[Behesht-e Zahra]], to the south of [[Tehran]], where the martyrs of the revolution and the war against Iraq are buried. On the other hand, some governments have banned this commemoration. In the 1930s [[Reza Shah]] forbade it in Iran. The regime of [[Saddam Hussein]] saw this as a potential threat and banned Ashura commemorations for many years.{{cite book |last1=Melton |first1=J. Gordon |last2=Baumann |first2=Martin |title=Religions of the World [6 volumes]: A Comprehensive Encyclopedia of Beliefs and Practices |year=2010 |publisher=ABC-CLIO |isbn=978-1598842036 |page=211 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=v2yiyLLOj88C&pg=PA211&lpg=PA211&dq=Reza+Shah+Ashura+banned&source=bl&ots=Zl6-wrja_w&sig=GLhqaO5kPG5NU-EQ0ckHdjkCabs&hl=fa&sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwjEsN2_lr_dAhXip4sKHTyMCRcQ6AEwDHoECAEQAQ#v=onepage&q=Reza%20Shah%20Ashura%20banned&f=false}} In the 1884 [[Hosay massacre]], 22 people were killed in [[Trinidad and Tobago]] when civilians attempted to carry out the Ashura rites, locally known as Hosay, in defiance of the British colonial authorities.{{cite book | author=[[Michael Anthony (author)|Anthony, Michael]] | title=Historical Dictionary of Trinidad and Tobago | publisher=Scarecrow Press, Inc. Lanham, MD and London | year=2001 |isbn=0810831732}} ==Violence during Ashura== Terrorist attacks against Shia Muslims have occurred in several countries, on the day of Ashurra.{{cite web|title=Anti-Shia Terror on Ashura Day|url=http://katehon.com/agenda/anti-shia-terror-ashura-day|website=Katehon think tank. While Ashura is always on the same day of the Islamic calendar, the date on the [[Gregorian calendar]] varies from year to year due to differences between the two calendars, since the Islamic calendar is a [[lunar calendar]] and the Gregorian calendar is a [[solar calendar]]. Furthermore, the appearance of the crescent moon that is used to determine when each Islamic month begins varies from country to country due to the different geographic locations. {|class="wikitable |- ![[Anno Hegirae|AH]] !Gregorian date |- |1438 |2016, October 12 (Middle East: Lebanon, Iraq, Iran) |- |1439 |2017,   October 1 (Middle East: Lebanon, Iraq, Iran){{cite web|title=Holidays in Iran in 2017|url=https://www.timeanddate.com/holidays/iraq/}} |- |1440 |2018, September 20 |- |1441 |2019,   September 9 |} ==Ashura in Chicago, United States== Every year on 10th Muharram hundreds take part in procession downtown for Muslim holiday of mourning. Many from Chicago’s Islamic communities donning black garb as a sign of mourning, turn out each year for the anniversary. The message of Ashura is universal and It is about standing up for what is right. At the Loop police blocked off streets for the procession of Ashura, which began and ended at the Thompson Center. Mosque leaders sang poems of mourning, and others carried colorful flags and banners, some bearing the names of those who died alongside Hussein. Many Muslims took off school for the holiday, as did many others marching down Randolph Street. After the yearly procession, many families go to pray at a mosque or gather at houses, where they often pray and reflect. '''Bodhisattvas of the Earth''', also sometimes referred to as "Bodhisattvas from the Underground," "Bodhisattvas Taught by the Original Buddha,"<ref>{{cite book|last1=Chitkara|first1=M. G.|title=Bodhisattva and selflessness|date=2002|publisher=APH Publ. Corp.|location=New Delhi|isbn=9788176481939|page=469}}</ref> or "earth bodhisattvas,"{{refn|group=note|name="deathplace"|Jaffe: "welling-up-out-of-the-earth bodhisattvas"<ref>Jaffe, P. D. (1986). [https://web.archive.org/web/20131230111535/http://nirc.nanzan-u.ac.jp/nfile/2326 Rising from the Lotus: Two bodhisattvas from the Lotus Sutra as a psychodynamic paradigm for Nichiren], Japanese Journal of Religious Studies 13 (1), 85</ref>}}<ref name="pbnshi.or.id">{{cite web|last1=Nakamura|first1=Jun-ichi|title=Nichiren Shonin and Those Who Uphold the Odaimoku Are All Bodhisattvas from Underground|url=http://www.pbnshi.or.id/?p=667|website=Perhimpunan Buddhis Nichiren Shu Indonesia|accessdate=29 July 2015}}</ref><ref name="Where the Buddha Lives Now">{{cite journal|last1=Leighton|first1=Taigen, Dan|title=Where the Buddha Lives Now|journal=Dharma World|date=2013|volume=40|issue=3|pages=18–21|url=http://www.kosei-shuppan.co.jp/english/text/mag/dindex.html|access-date=2015-08-02|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150714212810/http://www.kosei-shuppan.co.jp/english/text/mag/dindex.html#|archive-date=2015-07-14|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> are the infinite number of [[bodhisattva]]s who, in the 15th ("Emerging from the Earth") chapter of the [[Lotus Sutra]], emerged from a fissure in the ground.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Watson (Tr)|first1=Burton|title=The Lotus Sutra and Its Opening and Closing Sutras|date=2009|publisher=Soka Gakkai|location=Tokyo|isbn=9784412014091|pages=252, 253}}</ref> This pivotal story of the Lotus Sutra<ref name=Leighton3>{{cite book|last1=Leighton|first1=Taigen Dan|title=Visions of awakening space and time Dōgen and the Lotus sutra|date=2007|publisher=Oxford University Press|location=New York|isbn=9780195320930|page=4}}</ref> takes place during the "Ceremony in the Air" which had commenced in the 11th ("Emergence of the Treasure Tower") chapter. Later, in the 21st ("Supernatural Powers") chapter, Shakyamuni passes on to them the responsibility to keep and propagate the Lotus Sutra in the feared future era of the [[Three Ages of Buddhism|Latter Day of the Law]].<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Suzuki|first1=Takayasu|title=The Saddharmapundarika as the Prediction of All the Sentient Beings' Attaining Buddhahood: With Special Focus on the Sadaparibhuta-parivarta|journal=Journal of Indian and Buddhist studies|date=2016|volume=64|issue=3|page=1162|url=http://ci.nii.ac.jp/naid/110010051249/en}}</ref><ref name="The English Buddhist Dictionary Committee">{{Cite book| last =The English Buddhist Dictionary Committee| first =| authorlink =| coauthors =| title =The Soka Gakkai Dictionary of Buddhism| publisher =Motilal Banarsidass| year =2009| location =Delhi| pages =| url =http://www.sgilibrary.org/search_dict.php?id=175| doi =| id =| isbn =9788120833340}}{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
==Description== In the 15th ("Emerging from the Earth") chapter of the Lotus Sutra, the vast number of bodhisattvas from other realms who had appeared to hear Shakyamuni preach in the "Ceremony in the Air" hoped to receive the Buddha's permission to be the ones to propagate the Dharma in the perilous era to come.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Murano|first1=Senchu|title=An Outline of the Lotus Sūtra|journal=Contemporary Religions in Japan|date=1967|volume=8|issue=1|pages=50–51}}</ref>{{refn|group=note|name="Skt version"|Chapter 15 in Kumarajivas translation corresponds to chapter 14 ("Issuing of Bodhisattvas from the Gaps of the Earth") in the extant Sanskrit versions.<ref name=Pye>{{cite book|last1=Pye|first1=Michael|title=Skilful Means - A concept in Mahayana Buddhism|date=2003|publisher=Routledge|page=173|ISBN=0203503791}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Kern|first1=Hendrik |title=Saddharma Pundarîka or the Lotus of the True Law|publisher=Clarendon Press|location=Sacred Books of the East, Vol. XXI, Oxford|pages=281–297|url=http://www.sacred-texts.com/bud/lotus/index.htm}}</ref>}} To their great chagrin, Shakyamuni refused their request, deferring this honor to unnamed bodhisattvas who already existed in the empty space underneath the ''sahā-world'' [tr: "world of endurance of suffering, any world of transmigration"<ref>{{cite book|last1=Soothill|first1=W.E.|authorlink1=William Edward Soothill|last2=Hodous|first2=Lewis|authorlink2=Lewis Hodous|title=A Dictionary of Chinese Buddhist Terms|year=1937|publisher=London: Trübner|page=369}}</ref>].<ref>{{Citation|last=Suguro|first=Shinjo|last2=Nichiren Buddhist International Center|first2=trans.|title=Introduction to the Lotus Sutra|url=|year=1998|publisher=Jain Publishing Company|isbn=0875730787|pages=123-124}}</ref> Right after he made this statement the earth shook and a mighty fissure appeared. Dramatically, and in a single instant, bodhisattvas whose numbers are described in the sutra as "immeasurable, boundless, beyond anything that can be known through calculation, simile or parable" arose from the earth.<ref name=Watson>{{cite book|last1=Watson|first1=Burton, trans.|title=The Lotus sutra and its opening and closing sutras|date=2009|publisher=Soka Gakkai|location=Tokyo|isbn=978-4-412-01409-1|page=253}}</ref> All of them are "golden in hue, with the thirty-two features [of the Buddha] and an immeasurable brightness."<ref>Watson (2009), p. 252</ref>
These bodhisattvas had four leaders and guiding teachers: [[Visistacaritra|Superior Practices]] (the leader of the four), Boundless Practices, [[Visuddhacaritra|Pure Practices]], and [[Supratisthitacaritra|Firmly Established Practices]].<ref name="The English Buddhist Dictionary Committee"/><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Murano|first1=Senchu|title=An Outline of the Lotus Sūtra|journal=Contemporary Religions in Japan|date=1967|volume=8|issue=1|page=51}}</ref> The four leaders have been interpreted to represent the four [[bodhisattva vow]]s as practiced by the Mahayana traditions of China, Japan, and Korea<ref>{{cite book|last1=Niwano|first1=Nikkyo|title=Buddhism for today: a modern interpretation of the threefold lotus sutra|date=1975|publisher=Weatherhill|location=New York|isbn=9780834801479|edition=1st English|url=http://www.rk-world.org/publications/buddhismfortoday_B15.aspx|quote=1. Shujo muhen seigan-do. However innumerable living beings are, I vow to save them. (Steadfast Conduct)}}</ref> and are said to represent the four characteristics of Nirvana or Buddhahood as taught in the Lotus Sutra: true self, eternity, purity, and joy.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Morgan|first1=Diane|title=The Buddhist experience in America|date=2004|publisher=Greenwood Press|location=Westport, Conn. [u.a.]|isbn=9780313324918|page=121|edition=1. publ.}}</ref>
==Interpretations== According to [[Tao Sheng]] (ca. 360–434), the splitting of the earth and the welling forth of the bodhisattvas is indicative that "living beings inherently possess an endowment for enlightenment, and it cannot remain concealed; they are bound to break the earth of defilements and emerge to safeguard the Dharma.” <ref>{{cite book|last1=Kim|first1=Young-ho|title=Tao-sheng's commentary on the Lotus Sūtra : a study and translation|date=1990|publisher=State University of New York Press|location=Albany|isbn=0791402274|page=290}}</ref>
The allegory of the Bodhisattvas of the Earth in the 15th-21st chapters of the Lotus Sutra has affected the outlooks and practices of numerous Buddhist schools.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Leighton|first1=Taigen Dan|title=Vision of Awakening Space and Time Dogen and the Lotus Sutra.|date=2008|publisher=Oxford University Press, USA|location=Oxford|isbn=9780199724277|pages=41–47}}</ref> Although interpretations vary school by school, [[Thich Nhat Hanh]] provides a generalized reference: by rejecting the entreaties of bodhisattvas from other realms of the universe to propagate the Lotus Sutra after his death and by summoning countless bodhisattvas from under the earth, the Buddha affirms that he is from the world and the people of the world can rise to be its caretakers. In addition, he thus affirms the infinite universality of his life and the lives of all beings.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Hanh|first1=Thich Nhat|title=Peaceful action, open heart : lessons from the Lotus Sutra|date=2009|publisher=Parallax Press|location=Berkeley, Calif.|isbn=9781888375930|page=63}}</ref>
The welling forth of innumerable bodhisattvas from the earth has also been used as a metaphor for the emergence of a grassroots Buddhist movement.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Moon|first1=Susan|title=Not turning away : the practice of engaged Buddhism|date=2004|publisher=Shambhala|location=Boston|isbn=9781590301036|page=160|edition=1st}}</ref> The metaphor of the Bodhisattvas of the Earth is also being used in secular and ecumenical writing.<ref>{{cite book|last1=LaChance|first1=Albert J.|title=The architecture of the soul : a unitive model of the human person|date=2006|publisher=North Atlantic Books|location=Berkeley, Calif.|isbn=1556436025|pages=210–211|quote=We urgently need Bodhisattvas of the Earth from every creed--Jews, Christians, Moslems, Wiccans, Buddhists, Hindus, atheists, humanists, whatever. We must become primates of Earth, mammals of earth....The path of the Bodhisattva of the Earth starts where you are.}}</ref>
===Interpretation in Nichiren Buddhism=== Whereas [[Nichiren Buddhism|Nichiren Buddhists]] regard the first fourteen chapters as the transient or theoretical "Imprinted Gate," the "Emerging from the Earth" chapter (ch 15) is regarded as the opening of the Lotus Sutra's essential teachings (chapters 15-28), or the "Original Gate."<ref>{{cite book|last1=Tanabe|first1=George J. Jr.|last2=Tanabe|first2=Willa Jane|title=The Lotus Sutra in Japanese culture|date=1989|publisher=University of Hawaii Press|location=Honolulu|isbn=9780824811983|page=40|edition=Repr.}}</ref><ref name=McCormick1>{{cite web|last1=McCormick|first1=Ryuei Michael|title=Who's Who on the Gohonzon|url=http://nichirenscoffeehouse.net/ShuteiMandala/4bodhisattvas.html|publisher=nichirenscoffeehouse.net|access-date=2015-08-03|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160416113902/http://www.nichirenscoffeehouse.net/ShuteiMandala/4bodhisattvas.html#|archive-date=2016-04-16|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> The emergence of the Bodhisattvas of the Earth thus holds great significance. According to Kyōtsū Hori, "they are also called honge no bosatsu meaning bodhisattvas guided by the [[Eternal Buddha|Original Buddha]] in the eternal past."<ref name=Hori1>{{cite book|last1=Hori|first1=Kyōtsū|title=Writings of Nichiren Shōnin. Doctrine 1|date=2003|publisher=Nichiren Shū Overseas Propagation Promotion Association ; distributed by University of Hawai'i Press|location=Tokyo|isbn=0824827333|page=285|url=https://books.google.de/books?id=EloL0g-A0h0C&pg=PA290&lpg=PA290&dq=bodhisattvas+from+underground&source=bl&ots=CK-3IDo7Te&sig=1bPF9aYD848W8tMrXlab6RBwXCQ&hl=de&sa=X&ved=0CDAQ6AEwAmoVChMIts3A9q-LxwIVzJbbCh1tJAuH#v=onepage&q=bodhisattvas%20from%20underground&f=false}}</ref> [[Nichiren]] (1222–1282) self-identified himself as Bodhisattva Superior Practices,<ref>Jaffe, P. D. (1986). [https://web.archive.org/web/20131230111535/http://nirc.nanzan-u.ac.jp/nfile/2326 Rising from the Lotus: Two bodhisattvas from the Lotus Sutra as a psychodynamic paradigm for Nichiren], Japanese Journal of Religious Studies 13 (1), 85-86</ref> in several of his writings such as "The Opening of the Eyes." He claimed to qualify for this designation as the one who first grasped and taught the Mystic Law of [[Nam-myoho-renge-kyo]] in the Latter Day.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Leighton|first1=Taigen Dan|title=Vision of Awakening Space and Time Dogen and the Lotus Sutra.|date=2008|publisher=Oxford University Press, USA|location=Oxford|isbn=9780199724277|page=54}}</ref>
The four leaders of the Bodhisattvas of the Earth are represented on the top row of the [[Gohonzon]], the calligraphic mandala inscribed by [[Nichiren]], flanking the characters for Shakyamuni and Taho (Many Treasures) Buddhas.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nichiren-shu.org/boston/pages/Honzon/bodhisattva.htm|website=Nichiren-Shu.org|title=Honzon|publisher=Nichiren-shu|accessdate=23 July 2015}}</ref>
In his letter "The True Aspect of All Phenomena," Nichiren clearly stated that followers of his who spread and promote his teachings are fellow Bodhisattvas of the Earth: "There should be no discrimination among those who propagate the five characters of Myoho-renge-kyo in the Latter Day of the Law, be they men or women. Were they not Bodhisattvas of the Earth, they could not chant the daimoku. At first only Nichiren chanted Nam-myoho-renge-kyo, but then two, three, and a hundred followed, chanting and teaching others. Propagation will unfold this way in the future as well. Does this not signify 'emerging from the earth'?"<ref>Nichiren Daishonin, Soka Gakkai International (ed) (1999). The Writings of Nichiren Daishonin, Vol-1, p. 385.</ref>
The importance of the appearance of the Bodhisattvas of the Earth is underscored in most Nichiren schools: [[Soka Gakkai]],<ref>{{cite book|last1=Ikeda|first1=Daisaku|title=The heritage of the ultimate law of life|date=2009|publisher=World Tribune Press|location=Santa Monica, Calif.|isbn=9781938252280|pages=29, 32}}</ref> [[Nichiren Shū]], and [[Nichiren Shoshu]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Bodhisattvas of the Earth|url=http://www.nst.org/articles/bodhisattvas-of-the-earth/|website=Nichiren Shoshu Temple|publisher=NST|accessdate=23 July 2015}}</ref> The differing interpretations of how the Bodhisattvas of the Earth correspond to contemporary people are described below:
====Nichiren Shu==== Nichiren Shu states that its members aspire to the status of Bodhisattvas of the Earth.<ref name="pbnshi.or.id"/><ref>{{cite web|title=First International Lay Retreat ‘Determined to Be Bodhisattvas of the Earth’|url=http://www.nichiren-shu.org/newsletter/nichirenshu_news/NichirenSN175.pdf|website=Nichiren Shu News|publisher=Published by the Head Office of Nichiren-shu Buddhism & NOPPA|date=Dec 1, 2009}}</ref>
====Soka Gakkai==== The Soka Gakkai holds that all people who propagate the ideals of the Lotus Sutra are Bodhisattvas of the Earth.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Ikeda|first1=Daisaku|title=The Heart of the Lotus Sutra: The Mahayana Classic from Theory to Practice|date=2001|publisher=Middleway Press|isbn=0967469759|page=133|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=kH87BAAAQBAJ&pg=PA133&dq=bodhisattvas+of+the+earth&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CC0Q6AEwAWoVChMIzdzjrf_vxgIViG0eCh2IPwlZ#v=onepage&q=bodhisattvas%20of%20the%20earth&f=false|quote=All those who spread Buddhism in the defiled world of the Latter Day of the Law are, without exception, Bodhisattvas of the Earth. This day and age, SGI members match the description of the Bodhisattvas of the Earth perfectly.}}</ref> This realization is traced back to [[Josei Toda]]'s vision while imprisoned during World War II under the charge of [[lese-majeste|lèse-majesté]] in which he recognized himself as one of the Bodhisattvas of the Earth.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Prohl|first1=Inken|last2=Nelson|first2=John K.|title= Handbook of contemporary Japanese religions|date=2012|publisher=Brill|location=Leiden|isbn=9789004234369|pages=284–285}}</ref> [[Daisaku Ikeda]], president of the [[Soka Gakkai International]], often describes Soka Gakkai members as the present-day Bodhisattvas of the Earth.<ref>Daisaku Ikeda, The Heart of the Lotus Sutra. (2014). Middleway Press. pp. 133, 169, 337</ref>
====Nichiren Shoshu==== Nichiren Shoshu refers to its believers as "associates of the Bodhisattvas of the Earth," "sharing karmic bonds with the Bodhisattvas of the Earth," or as "followers of the Bodhisattvas of the Earth." There are occasional references to the laity and priests of Nichiren Shoshu being the Bodhisattvas of the Earth.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Shogu|first1=Kimura|title=Upholding Faith and Practice with a Solid Vow|url=http://www.nichirenshoshumyoshinji.org/sermons/2010/06_10_oko.php|website=Nichiren Shoshu Myoshinji Temple|publisher=Nichiren Shoshu Temple|accessdate=24 July 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150724071649/http://www.nichirenshoshumyoshinji.org/sermons/2010/06_10_oko.php#|archive-date=2015-07-24|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Bodhisattvas of the Earth|url=http://www.nst.org/articles/bodhisattvas-of-the-earth/|website=Nichiren Shoshu Temple|publisher=Nichiren Shoshu Temple|accessdate=23 July 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Shonin|first1=Nichinyo|title=Guidance from Sixty-eighth High Priest Nichinyo Shonin: On the Occasion of the June Kosen-rufu Shodai Ceremony June 2, 2013|url=http://www.nstny.org/Documents/Myosetsuji News Sept_13.pdf|website=Nichiren Shoshu Temple of New York|publisher=Nichiren Shoshu Temple of New York|accessdate=24 July 2015}}</ref>
===Interpretation in Lotus Sutra Schools=== According to the [[Risshō Kōsei Kai]], the appearance of the Bodhisattvas of the Earth represent a shift from teachings of theory in the first half of the Lotus Sutra to teachings about conduct and human action, teachings that are applicable to life today.{{refn|group=note|name="first half of the Lotus Sutra"|Nikkyō Niwano: "The first half of the Lotus Sutra was given over largely to the teaching of reason and truth, the teaching of wisdom. But upon completion of that half of the sutra, we had the abrupt appearance of a countless throng of bodhisattvas who were doers. Any teaching without application in practice, in conduct, is nothing. It must move on to the stage of action. True bodhisattvas are the doers who apply their knowledge of the true aspect of all reality, the statement of which truth is the theme of the first half of the Lotus Sutra. They are the doers who, in their compassionate conduct, exemplify the truth of the buddha-nature identity: the kind of persons who make the teaching of the Buddha meaningful in this world. Since this so precisely applies to us who are alive today, it is important to take the message to heart."<ref>{{cite book|last1=Niwano|first1=Nikkyō|title=A guide to the Threefold Lotus Sutra|date=1982|publisher=Kosei Publ. Co.|location=Tokyo|isbn=978-4333010257|edition=2. print.|url=http://www.rk-world.org/publications/guidels_B15.aspx|quote=}}</ref>}} Reeves suggests that the massive emergence of the Bodhisattvas from the Earth, born from the ground of daily life, is an ongoing process, not a one-time story.{{refn|group=note|name="the power to see the buddha in others"|Reeves: "The text says that the four groups, the monks and nuns, laymen and laywomen, could see these bodhisattvas "by the divine powers of the Buddha." This is another way of referring to the human imagination, to the power that we all have to transcend everyday life, the power to see the buddha in others."<ref>{{cite book|last1=Reeves|first1=Gene|title=The stories of the Lotus sutra|date=2010|publisher=Wisdom Publications|location=Boston|isbn=0861716469|page=195|quote=}}</ref>}}
[[Nikkyo Niwano]] describes a humanistic tone to the ways the emerging bodhisattvas greet the Buddha, inquiring about his health and the receptions of people to his teachings. The implication is that the Buddha, as a religion founder, is not a godhead or the recipient of a divine revelation. Rather, his enlightenment stemmed from his own personal efforts.{{refn|group=note|name="different "|Reeves: "In this respect, Buddhism...is quite different from most, perhaps all, other religions."<ref>{{cite book|last1=Reeves|first1=Gene|title=The stories of the Lotus sutra|date=2010|publisher=Wisdom Publications|location=Boston|isbn=0861716469|page=193|quote=}}</ref>}}
===Interpretation in the Sōtō Zen School=== [[Dōgen]], the founder of the Japanese [[Sōtō]] Zen school, made more references to the Lotus Sutra in his commentaries than any other sutras. His commentaries focused primarily on the 15th (Emerging from the Earth) and 16th (Life Span) Chapters of the Lotus Sutra. Dōgen made numerous speculations about the significance of the bodhisattvas who emerged from the underground.<ref name=Leighton>{{Citation|last=Leighton |first=Taigen Dan |title=Dogen's Appropriation of Lotus Sutra Ground and Space |journal=Japanese Journal of Religious Studies |year=2005 |volume=32 |issue=1 |pages=85–105 |url=http://nirc.nanzan-u.ac.jp/nfile/2862 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140109095128/http://nirc.nanzan-u.ac.jp/nfile/2862 |archivedate=January 9, 2014 }}</ref>
As conceived by Dōgen, the stories of the underground bodhisattvas and the Buddha's inconceivable life-span serve as a fundamental shift in the development of East Asian Mahayana understanding of Buddhahood, an immediate attainment based on fundamental awakening rather than an achievement based on lifetimes of arduous practice.<ref>Leighton 2005, pp. 85–105</ref> This can be conceived as "Shortening the Path"<ref>{{cite book|last1=Groner|first1=Paul|editor1-last=|editor1-first=|editor2-last=|editor2-first=|editor1-link=|title=Shortening the Path: Early Tendai Interpretations of the Realization of Buddhahood with This Very Body. In Buswell, Robert; Gimello, Robert (eds), Paths to Liberation: The Mårga and Its Transformation in Buddhist Thought|date=1992|publisher=University of Hawaii Press|location=Honolulu|pages=439–474}}</ref> or a transition from a "progress philosophy" to a "leap philosophy."<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Potter|first1=Karl|title=The Naturalistic Principle of Karma|journal=Philosophy East & West|date=April 1964|volume=14|page=43|publisher=University of Hawaii Press}}</ref>

In [[Ancient Rome]], the term "'''carmen'''" was generally used to signify a [[Verse (poetry)|verse]]; but in its proper sense, it referred to a [[Spell (paranormal)|spell]] or [[prayer]], form of [[expiation]], [[execration]], etc. Surviving examples include the ''[[Carmen Arvale]]'' and the ''[[Carmen Saliare]]''.<ref name="cyclo">{{1728}}</ref>
==Purposes== Spells and incantations were used for a variety of purposes. If a spell was intended to harm someone, the State could interfere to protect him. For instance, it was not unusual for a farmer whose crops had failed to accuse another farmer of having, by a ''carmen'', lured the crops away. [[Tibullus]], in a poem in which he complains that an old woman has bewitched Marathus, takes the opportunity to recount various feats of witches, such as transferring crops from one field to another. Similarly, [[Pliny the Elder]] records in ''[[Naturalis Historia]]'' (XVIII. 8) that a certain [[freedman]], Furius, by using better implements and better methods than his neighbor, obtained richer crops from a smaller strip of land. A neighbor compelled Furius to go before the tribes and accused him of having bewitched his field. But when the tribes saw his sturdy slaves and his implements of witchcraft—hoes, rakes, and ploughs—they acquitted him.<ref name="tms">Burriss, Eli Edward. ''[http://www.sacred-texts.com/cla/tms/tms00.htm Taboo, Magic, Spirits: A Study of Primitive Elements in Roman Religion]''. New York, Macmillan Company. 1931. Public domain.</ref><ref>http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus:text:1999.02.0137:book=18:chapter=8&highlight=furius</ref>
==Chanting== That incantations were chanted is a matter of common observance and scarcely needs illustration. For example, in magic rites, the purpose of which was to induce a dislocated or broken bone to come together, the incantation was sung (''cantare''). Tibullus writes that a witch composed a charm for him, to be chanted three times, after which he had to spit; then Delia's husband would believe gossip about other lovers of Delia, but not about her and Tibullus.<ref name="tms"/>
The two oldest prayers of the Romans which are still known—the ''[[Carmen Arvale]]'' and the ''[[Carmen Saliare]]''—were both chanted. [[Livy]] writes that "the leaping priests went through the city chanting their hymns." There is reason to believe that the old prayers which [[Cato the Elder|Cato]] has preserved in his treatise on agriculture were originally in metrical form; but in the directions given to the worshiper, the verb ''dicito'', and not ''cantato'', precedes the prayer, showing that, in Cato's time at least, such prayers were ''spoken'' rather than sung. However, these prayers, even in the form in which they are found in Cato, are predominantly [[spondaic]], in keeping with the slow movement of the chant and with the solemn religious character of the rites. In ceremonies intended to bring thunderbolts down from the sky, incantations were used.<ref name="tms"/>
==Repetition== Repetition characterized the magic incantation. For instance, the incantation of the lover in [[Virgil]]'s eighth ''[[Eclogue]]'', already referred to, was repeated nine times; the incantation which the witch formulated for Tibullus had to be uttered three times. At the conclusion of the prayer to [[Pales]] is the following: "With these words the goddess must be appeased. So do you, facing the east, utter them four times...." The verses of the ''Carmen Saliare'' were each chanted three times, as the Leaping Priests of [[Mars (mythology)|Mars]] danced in threefold measure. [[William Warde Fowler|W. Warde Fowler]], who on the whole is not inclined to identify spell and prayer, writes in ''The Religious Experience of the Roman People'' (1911) that the verses "seem certainly to belong rather to the region of magic than of religion proper." Repetition was also characteristic of the ''Carmen Arvale'' and the prayer of the [[Fratres Attiedii]].<ref name="tms"/>
==Etymology== ''Carmen'' is derived from the root ''canere'' (meaning "to sing") with the passive nominal ending -''men'' (therefore "a thing sung," cf. ''flumen'' from ''fluere'' or ''numen'' from ''nuere'').<ref>Lewis, C. T. & Short, C. 1879, ''A Latin Dictionary'', New York: Harper and Brothers; see the entry under '''carmen'''.</ref><ref>http://www.etymonline.com/index.php?term=charm&allowed_in_frame=0</ref>

The '''Coalition to Investigate the Persecution of Falun Gong in China (CIPFG)''' is an international [[non-governmental organization]] established in the [[United States]] on April 5, 2006 by the Falun Dafa Association.<ref>{{cite web |author=Thomas Lum |url=https://fpc.state.gov/documents/organization/67820.pdf |title=CRS Report for Congress #RL33437. China and Falun Gong |page=CRS-7 paragraph 3 |publisher=[[Congressional Research Service]] |date=May 25, 2006}}</ref><ref name="implicates">{{cite news |url=http://www.taipeitimes.com/News/front/archives/2006/07/08/2003317781 |title=Canadian report implicates China in organ harvesting |author=[[Agence France-Presse]] |date=July 8, 2006 |publisher=[[Taipei Times]]}}</ref> The organization also has offices in [[Canada]].<ref name="implicates"/>
In 2006, the organization asked former Canadian Secretary of State [[David Kilgour]] and human rights lawyer [[David Matas]] to investigate allegations of [[Falun Gong and live organ harvesting|organ harvesting]] from Falun Gong practitioners in China. The [[Kilgour–Matas report]]<ref name=KM/> concluded that, "the government of China and its agencies in numerous parts of the country, in particular hospitals but also detention centres and 'people's courts', since 1999 have put to death a large but unknown number of Falun Gong prisoners of conscience.<ref name=KM>[[David Kilgour]], [[David Matas]] (6 July 2006, revised 31 January 2007) [http://organharvestinvestigation.net An Independent Investigation into Allegations of Organ Harvesting of Falun Gong Practitioners in China] (in 22 languages) organharvestinvestigation.net</ref>
== History == [[Image:Human Rights Abuse Cannot Co-exist with Beijing Olympics.jpg|thumb|right|Human Rights Torch Relay protesters, the banner reads: "Human Rights Abuse Cannot Co-exist with Beijing Olympics"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thewhig.com/ArticleDisplay.aspx?e=1034514&auth=Jordan+Press |title=Newspaper |publisher=Thewhig.com |date=2009-12-01 |accessdate=2009-12-18}}</ref>]] In December 2006, the Australian government responded to the newly formed CIPFG's petition alleging unethical [[Organ transplantation in China|organ transplant procedures in China]] by announcing the abolition of training programs for Chinese doctors in organ transplant procedures in the Prince Charles and the Princess Alexandra Hospitals as well as ending their joint research programs into organ transplantation with China.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.smh.com.au/news/National/Hospitals-ban-Chinese-surgeon-training/2006/12/05/1165080933418.html |title=Hospitals ban training Chinese surgeons |author=[[Sydney Morning Herald]] |date=December 5, 2006 |publisher=smh.com }}</ref>
The Coalition to Investigate the Persecution of Falun Gong organized the international Global Human Rights Torch Relay that traveled through 150 cities in 35 countries of Europe, Asia, North America and Australasia to support a boycott of the [[2008 Summer Olympics|2008 Beijing Olympics]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.scoop.co.nz/stories/PO0712/S00326.htm |title=Wakas To Bring Human Rights Torch Into Nelson |author=CIPFG}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/section/2/story.cfm?c_id=2&objectid=10482783 |title=Human rights marchers want Olympic boycott |author=Alanah May Eriksen |date=December 17, 2007 |publisher=[[New Zealand Herald]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Calgary |first=The |url=http://www.canada.com/calgaryherald/news/city/story.html?id=4b4fd555-3455-40ba-b594-3cd16aa28624 |title=City rally hears student's tale of torture, imprisonment in China |publisher=Canada.com |date=2008-05-20 |accessdate=2009-12-18}}</ref> The relay started in Athens on 9 August 2007, one year before the start of the Olympic Games. According to CIPFG, the role of the Human Rights Torch Relay was to raise awareness of [[Human rights in the People's Republic of China]], especially the [[persecution of Falun Gong]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://mwcnews.net/content/view/22620&Itemid=1 |title=A Site Without Borders - - Human Rights Torch Comes to Vancouver |publisher=MWC News |date=2007-08-09 |accessdate=2009-12-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080929152141/http://mwcnews.net/content/view/22620%26Itemid%3D1 |archivedate=September 29, 2008 |df= }}</ref> Some celebrities participated in the march, such as Chen Kai, a former member of China’s national [[basketball]] team.<ref name=autogenerated1>{{cite web |url=http://news.medill.northwestern.edu/chicago/news.aspx?id=89005 |title=Activists carry torch to protest human-rights violations in China |publisher=News.medill.northwestern.edu |date=2008-05-14 |accessdate=2009-12-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110930160809/http://news.medill.northwestern.edu/chicago/news.aspx?id=89005 |archivedate=2011-09-30 |df= }}</ref>
